title: UK foreign aid cut: Where does it go and what is it used for?
description: The UK's foreign aid spend will come down from 0.7% of national income to 0.5%.

title: Job Maseko: The South African WW2 hero who didn't get a Victoria Cross
description: Job Maseko blew up a German ship but his bravery was not properly recognised because he was black, campaigners say.

title: How US police training compares with the rest of the world
description: Amid calls to improve training in the US, we examine how it compares with other developed countries.

title: Medical cannabis 'saved my life'
description: A student tells how medical cannabis means she is no longer living in pain.

title: Mental health and pregnancy: 'I couldn't hold my baby for more than a minute'
description: A mental health crisis during pregnancy 'broke my brain' and left Seaneen unable to hold baby Jack.

title: Powerful portraits of girls on the cusp of adolescence
description: Carolyn Mendelsohn spent six years photographing dozens of girls aged between 10 and 12.

title: Working from home: 'Why not work in the car?'
description: A support worker who relocated her office to her car during lockdown says she plans to stay put.

title: Russia spy chief suggests West behind SolarWinds cyber-attack
description: Sergei Naryshkin speaks to the BBC in a rare interview about 2020's SolarWinds cyber-attack in the US.

title: Should encryption be curbed to combat child abuse?
description: Cyber-security experts, tech firms and lawyers weigh in on the end-to-end encryption debate.

title: India coronavirus: Tracing a family’s journey to save a life
description: A family's heartbreaking journey between two cities to find a bed for a gasping Covid-19 patient.

title: In pictures: Lockdown eases in parts of the UK
description: Images from the day, as coronavirus rules are eased in England, Scotland and Wales.

title: 'Are you crying?' First mum-daughter hug in a year
description: Front-line NHS worker Viv Hudson hasn't hugged her daughter for over a year – until now.

title: Covid vaccine: Young teens in US react to getting first jab
description: The first children aged 12 to 15 have begun getting Covid vaccines after the US widened eligibility.

title: Holidaying Brits touch down in Portugal: 'It feels unreal'
description: Leisure travel from England, Scotland and Wales, to a select number of countries, is now allowed.

title: Why is Huawei still in the UK?
description: Huawei defends its links with British universities, says it admires UK innovation

title: Bee swarm thwarts Colchester gym-goer's journey home
description: Justin Stone needed the help of a passer-by to help remove hundreds of bees from his car.

title: River Nene: Croquet match decides river's pronunciation
description: One team says "Nen", the other says "Neen", and they call it off after a battle with mallets.

title: 'Really moving' to perform first post-lockdown comedy show
description: Comedian Barry Ferns put on a show as soon as lockdown rules were eased at one minute past midnight.

title: Long working hours killing 745,000 people a year, study finds
description: The World Health Organization says the trend may worsen due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Thousands head off for overseas holidays
description: Holidaymakers from England, Scotland and Wales are now able to jet off for some early summer sun.

title: Train derails and explodes into flames
description: The freight train was carrying highly flammable fertiliser and nearby residents have been evacuated.

title: Former players launch petition calling for independent regulator in English football
description: Former footballers, including Gary Neville, Jamie Carragher, Rio Ferdinand and Gary Lineker, launch parliamentary petition calling for an independent regulator in English football.

title: Covid: More than 6,000 vaccinated in Bolton over variant
description: Thousands of people got jabs in Bolton over the weekend as the town battles the Indian variant.

title: Covid-19: Lockdowns ease in England, Wales and most of Scotland
description: Rules on socialising indoors and foreign travel are lifted in England, Wales and most of Scotland.

title: Israel-Gaza: Why is the region blurry on Google Maps?
description: High-resolution images of Israel and Gaza are available, so why not via public mapping tools?

title: How to deal with social anxiety with new-found freedom
description: The new-found freedoms for England, Scotland and Wales can be tough for those with anxiety.

title: 'The passion is no longer there' - Eastmond retires from professional rugby
description: Leeds' dual code international Kyle Eastmond retires from professional rugby saying he has lost "the passion to influence the game".

title: Belgian ambassador's wife claims diplomatic immunity over Seoul slap
description: The wife of Belgium's ambassador to South Korea is seen slapping a shop worker in CCTV footage.

title: Firms call for more help after 'haemorrhaging cash'
description: Despite lockdown easing, businesses say they need more support to manage the impact of the last year.

title: Llandudno's Kashmiri goats invited to I'm A Celeb castle
description: They wreaked havoc in Llandudno - now they have been invited to the Welsh home of I'm A Celebrity...

title: Fury confirms Joshua showdown set for 14 August in Saudi Arabia
description: Tyson Fury says his all-British world heavyweight title showdown with Anthony Joshua will take place in Saudi Arabia on 14 August.

title: Brexit: UK proposes new Irish Sea food checks from October
description: The details are contained in a roadmap shared with the EU, which has been seen by the BBC.

title: The Papers: 'Don't blow it, Britain' as nations 'open up'
description: The relaxation of lockdown rules, plus the warnings to remain "cautious", dominate Monday's papers.

title: India's Covid crisis hits Covax vaccine-sharing scheme
description: The largest single supplier to the international Covax scheme has made no shipments since March.
